meta.title: Is My Toddler Ready for Potty Training?
meta.description: A research-backed assessment to help you determine if your toddler is ready to start potty training. Based on AAP guidelines.
meta.intro:
Most children show signs of readiness between 18 months and 3 years, but every child is different. This quiz assesses readiness across three research-backed domains: physical readiness, cognitive awareness, and emotional readiness.

Answer based on what your child does NOW, not what you hope they'll do soon.

questions.text: Can your child stay dry for at least 2 hours at a time during the day?
questions.subtext: Check their diaper after naps or quiet play periods.
questions.source: Mayo Clinic - bladder control maturation indicator

questions.text: Does your child have predictable bowel movements?
questions.subtext: Around the same time each day, or after meals.
questions.source: AAP - bowel regularity as readiness indicator

questions.text: Can your child walk to the bathroom and sit on a potty or toilet?
Can your child pull their pants up and down?
Does your child show awareness when they're peeing or pooping?
questions.subtext: Stops playing, squats, goes to a corner, makes a face, or tells you.

questions.text: Can your child follow simple 2-step instructions?
questions.subtext: Example: "Get your shoes and bring them here."
questions.source: AAP - cognitive readiness for understanding potty training steps

questions.text: Does your child understand basic potty-related words?
questions.subtext: Words like: pee, poop, wet, dry, potty.
questions.source: Mayo Clinic - language comprehension as readiness indicator

options.text: Yes, understands and uses some words
Understands but doesn't use the words

questions.text: Does your child show discomfort with wet or dirty diapers?
questions.subtext: Asks to be changed, pulls at diaper, says "yucky" or similar.

options.text: Yes, clearly dislikes being wet or dirty
Doesn't seem to notice or care

questions.text: Does your child show interest in the bathroom or toilet?
questions.subtext: Curious about others using the toilet, wants to watch, asks questions.

questions.text: Is your child in a generally cooperative phase right now?
questions.subtext: Not in a major "no to everything" phase.
questions.source: AAP - timing recommendation to avoid power struggles

high.headline: Body is ready
high.detail: Your child has developed the bladder control and motor skills needed for potty training. They can stay dry for reasonable periods and have the physical coordination to use the toilet.
high.strength: Strong physical readiness - your child's body has matured enough for toilet training

medium.headline: Physical skills emerging
medium.detail: Your child is developing the physical control needed, but it's not fully consistent yet. This often improves quickly over a few weeks.
medium.concern: Physical control is still developing - you may see more accidents if you start now

low.headline: Physical maturation in progress
low.detail: Your child's body is still developing the bladder and bowel control needed for potty training. This is developmental, not behavioral - it simply takes time.
low.concern: Physical readiness typically develops between 18-30 months. Your child's body needs more time.

high.headline: Understands the concept
high.detail: Your child can recognize body signals, follow instructions, and understands what the potty is for. This cognitive foundation makes training much smoother.
high.strength: Strong cognitive awareness - your child understands the process and can communicate about it

medium.headline: Building understanding
medium.detail: Your child is starting to connect the dots but may not fully grasp all the steps yet. Keep talking about it casually to build familiarity.
medium.concern: Cognitive understanding is building - expect to repeat instructions often and be patient with confusion

low.headline: Still developing comprehension
low.detail: Your child isn't yet making the connection between body sensations and what to do about them. This is completely normal, especially under age 2.
low.concern: The cognitive connections needed for potty training typically develop between ages 2-3

high.headline: Motivated and cooperative
high.detail: Your child is interested in the toilet, bothered by wet diapers, and in a cooperative phase. This motivation is a huge advantage.
high.strength: Strong emotional readiness - your child WANTS to do this, which makes everything easier

medium.headline: Interest emerging
medium.detail: Your child shows some interest but isn't fully motivated yet. Nurturing this curiosity without pressure can help it grow.
medium.concern: Motivation is still building - forcing it now could create resistance

low.headline: Not motivated yet
low.detail: Your child isn't showing interest in the toilet and isn't bothered by diapers. That's okay - interest often emerges suddenly when the time is right.
low.concern: Without internal motivation, potty training becomes a power struggle. Let interest develop naturally.

ready.headline: Green Light!
ready.subheadline: Your toddler is showing strong readiness signs.
ready.explanation: Your child is demonstrating readiness across all three domains: physical control, cognitive awareness, and emotional willingness. Research shows that children who start potty training when truly ready typically complete the process faster and with fewer setbacks.
nextSteps: Pick a calm week to start - avoid major transitions like new siblings, moving, or starting daycare
Let your child pick out underwear or a potty seat to build excitement
Use your child's natural motivation - children who are ready often train quickly with gentle guidance
Expect some accidents and treat them matter-of-factly, not as failures
ready.watchOutFor: Even ready children may regress during stress, illness, or big life changes. If this happens, it's normal - stay patient and don't treat it as a step backward.
ready.encouragement: You've waited for the right time, which sets you up for success. Trust your child's readiness and your own instincts.
ready.comparativeContext: Most parents who score in this range successfully potty train within 1-2 weeks.

almost.headline: Yellow Light
almost.subheadline: Your toddler is getting there - a few more weeks may help.
almost.explanation: Your child is showing some readiness signs but may not have all the pieces in place yet. Starting now could work with extra patience, but waiting 2-4 weeks often leads to a smoother process.
nextSteps: Don't pressure, but DO prepare: read potty books together, let them observe, talk about it casually
Watch for the missing readiness signs to emerge naturally
Consider a gentle introduction - a potty chair in the bathroom, sitting on it clothed
Retake this quiz in 2-4 weeks to check progress
almost.watchOutFor: If you decide to start now, watch for daily battles or increasing resistance. These are signals to pause and try again later - not signs of failure.
almost.encouragement: Your child is close! A little more time often makes a big difference. The readiness signs you're already seeing are great progress.
almost.comparativeContext: Most parents in this range find their child ready within 2-3 months.

not-yet.headline: Not Quite Yet
not-yet.subheadline: Your toddler needs more time - and that's completely okay.
not-yet.explanation: Your child isn't showing consistent readiness signs yet. This is normal and has nothing to do with intelligence or your parenting. Children trained before they're ready actually take longer to complete the process and have more accidents.
nextSteps: Zero pressure - avoid making potty training feel like a test or expectation
Casually introduce the concept through books, observation, and play
Keep diapers without any shame - "Diapers are for kids who aren't ready yet. You'll be ready when your body is ready."
Watch for readiness signs to emerge over the next few months
not-yet.watchOutFor: Well-meaning family members may pressure you to start. Remember: research clearly shows that early training doesn't lead to earlier completion - it just leads to a longer, harder process.
not-yet.encouragement: The average age for completing potty training is 2.5 to 3.5 years. Your child's timeline is their own, and waiting for readiness is the evidence-based approach.
not-yet.comparativeContext: Most children develop these readiness signs between ages 2 and 3 â€” you're right on track.
